CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6+6-3-c - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Criminal proceedings;Article 6-1 - Fair hearing) (Article 6 - Right to a fair trial;Article 6-3-c - Defence through legal assistance;Legal assistance of his own choosing);Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - award

TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE . He is currently serving a prison sentence in PERSON prison .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested and his apartment was searched by the police . He was subsequently remanded in custody from DATE until DATE . In a judgment of DATE the ORG found the applicant guilty of burglary and sentenced him to CARDINAL and a half years’ imprisonment . The applicant , who was at that time in detention for the purposes of another criminal case against him , was represented before the court by a legalaid lawyer , GPE

CARDINAL . On DATE the lawyer submitted his appeal to the court . By a letter of DATE the court , apparently unaware of the fact that the applicant remained in detention in connection with another criminal case , informed the applicant that the appeal submitted by the lawyer had been declared admissible . This letter was sent by registered letter to the applicant ’s home address and served on his wife . The court considered it to have been properly served on the party as required by the applicable laws . The appeal itself was neither sent to the applicant nor served on him .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the court sent another letter to the applicant ’s home address , informing him that his legalaid lawyer had been replaced by another one , ORG This letter was not collected from the post office within the statutory period and was returned to the registry of the court . The court considered , in compliance with the applicable provisions of criminal procedure , that it had been properly served on the applicant .
CARDINAL . Subsequently , the court sent a summons to the hearing before the appellate court to the applicant ’s home address . It was not served on him as he remained in detention .

CARDINAL . The new legalaid lawyer did not get in touch with the applicant . The applicant learned from CARDINAL of the inmates in GPE prison that an appeal had been lodged in his case and that a hearing was soon to be held . On DATE he wrote a letter to the court requesting it to postpone the hearing and to be brought before the court . He also submitted his own arguments in support of the appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE a hearing was held , in the applicant ’s absence , before ORG . The court dismissed the lawyer ’s appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was informed by the registry of the court that his request of DATE and his appeal had been submitted to the court after the hearing of DATE . On DATE the applicant complained to the court that he had been unable to participate in the hearing .
CARDINAL . On DATE a copy of the judgment given by the appellate court was sent to the prison where the applicant was detained at that time .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested legal aid for the purpose of preparing a cassation appeal against the judgment of CARDINAL DATE . On DATE he submitted a detailed complaint to ORG about the fact that he had not been properly notified of the hearing , that the legalaid lawyer had been replaced without his knowing it , that he had neither been served with a copy of the appeal nor informed that it had been accepted for examination , and that he could not participate in the hearing . He was of the view that his defence rights had thereby been breached and that the conviction was in any event not safe , given the errors committed by the first - instance court in the assessment of the evidence .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON , the same lawyer who had represented the applicant before the appellate court , was assigned to the case . On DATE the court , referring to LAW , informed the applicant that he had not been entitled in law to have a copy of the lawyer ’s appeal served on him , and that the summons had been served at his home address .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted his own cassation appeal to ORG . He reiterated the procedural complaints which he had made in respect of the appellate proceedings . He also argued that the court had failed to take into consideration circumstances pointing to his innocence .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was informed that he had been granted legal aid for the purposes of the cassation proceedings . On DATE PERSON notified the court and the applicant that he had found no grounds on which to prepare a cassation appeal . The applicant was served with this letter on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint against ORG with ORG . He submitted , essentially , that he should not have been assigned to represent him in the cassation proceedings , given what had happened in the proceedings before the appellate court . On DATE he requested the court to accept his own cassation appeal for examination .
CARDINAL . ORG answered on DATE , stating that ORG had been right to refuse to prepare a cassation appeal in the applicant ’s case .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged further pleadings in support of his cassation appeal dated DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG refused to accept the applicant ’s cassation appeal as it had not been prepared and signed by a lawyer as required by law . The applicant appealed . On DATE the court summoned him to have that appeal submitted by a lawyer .
CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE ORG informed the applicant that a legalaid lawyer was , under the applicable laws , entitled to refuse to prepare a cassation appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG refused to accept for examination the applicant ’s appeal against the decision of DATE , finding that it should have been submitted by a lawyer . On DATE an appeal by the applicant against that decision was dismissed by ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG found the applicant guilty of attempted car theft and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . The applicant appealed . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant issued a request to have both judgments quashed and his case re - examined by the first - instance court . He argued that new evidence had emerged , namely the statement of ORG , who had confessed to the crime of which the applicant had been found guilty .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the request . The court found PERSON ’s statement “ implausible ” .

CARDINAL . In DATE a new Code of Criminal Procedure was enacted . Article CARDINAL of the Code provided that an appellate court could order that a defendant be remanded in custody ( under NORP law remand in custody is terminated only by a secondinstance judgment ) and be brought to the courtroom to attend a hearing before that court .
Article CARDINAL of LAW Procedure reads :
“ § CARDINAL . A court of appeal shall not be allowed to conduct evidentiary proceedings pertaining to the merits of the case .

§ CARDINAL . In exceptional cases the appellate court may , if it finds the completion of a judicial examination necessary , nevertheless accept new evidence directly at the hearing , if this will expedite the judicial proceedings and there is no necessity to conduct the whole of the proceedings , or a major part thereof , anew . Before the hearing the court may issue an order on the admission of evidence . ”

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG adopted a resolution stating that during a hearing before an appellate court a defendant should at least have an opportunity to defend him- or herself , or to be represented by a defence lawyer ( DATE , PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG stated that it was mandatory to bring the defendant to a hearing before the appellate court , regardless of whether he or she had made a relevant request ( V KKN CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG stated that in cases in which the arguments made in the statement of appeal were limited to challenging exclusively the legal aspects of a case or where only the sentence was challenged , a decision not to bring a defendant represented by a lawyer before the appellate court was correct ( III KKN CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . In DATE Article CARDINAL of the Code was amended , in response to the ORG ’s judgment in the case of Belziuk v. GPE ( Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINAL ) . The amended provision read :

“ The appellate court shall order an accused , who is detained , to be brought to the appellate hearing , unless it finds that the presence of his lawyer is sufficient . If the court decides not to bring an accused who has no defence counsel to the hearing it shall appoint for him ex officio a legal - aid lawyer . ”

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG examined the ORG ’s request for clarification of issues relating to the presence of the accused at the appeal hearing . In its resolution of DATE the court expressed the view that the right to a fair hearing demanded that the person convicted by the first - instance court should be informed of his right to request to be brought before the appellate court , and should be brought to such a hearing . ORG stated :

“ ... Finally , it should be underlined that even if the accused requests to be brought to an appeal hearing , the court may establish that the presence of the lawyer at the appeal hearing would be sufficient . If the accused does not have counsel , it is necessary to appoint a legalaid lawyer for him , whose presence at the hearing would be obligatory . It should however be noted that if an accused deprived of liberty requests to be brought to an appeal hearing , granting such a request should be a rule ... Finding that the presence of the lawyer would be sufficient could occur in particular if the appeal hearing concerned only questions of law . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE extensive amendments to LAW , adopted in DATE , entered into force . Under LAW CARDINAL as amended it became obligatory for an appellate court to inform the accused of his or her right to request leave to attend the hearing before that court . However , proceedings in which hearings before the trial court started before DATE were to be governed by the provisions of the Code as they stood before that date .

CARDINAL . ORG has examined , in numerous judgments , cassation appeals based on the allegation that the absence of an accused at the appeal hearing was a flagrant breach of law that could significantly affect the substance of the ruling in question , within the meaning of Article CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure .

CARDINAL . ORG on many occasions found that a refusal to bring the accused to the appeal hearing was a flagrant breach of law that could significantly affect the substance of the second - instance judgment . In such cases , ORG quashed the appeal judgment and remitted the case ( judgment of DATE , III KKN CARDINAL/CARDINAL , judgment of DATE , III KKN CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . In a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG held that when the defendant remanded in custody was unable to have effective contact with his legalaid lawyer and was not summoned to the hearing before the appellate court because the summons had been sent to his home address , the defendant ’s defence rights had been breached . This breach was of such a serious character that the judgment of the appellate court given in the applicant ’s absence , even when he was represented by the lawyer , had to be quashed .

CARDINAL . Under LAW of the LAW , an accused may appoint a lawyer to represent him or her in criminal proceedings . If he or she can not afford lawyers’ fees , a request for legal aid may be made under LAW of the LAW . Legal representation for the purposes of cassation proceedings is mandatory . In its decisions of CARDINAL DATE and CARDINAL DATE ORG expressed the view that when a legalaid lawyer refused to represent a convicted person before ORG , the appellate court was not obliged to assign a new lawyer to the case ( II KZ CARDINAL/CARDINAL , II KZ CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Under LAW of the LAW , an accused may appoint a lawyer to represent him or her in criminal proceedings . If he or she can not afford lawyers’ fees , a request for legal aid may be made under LAW of the Code .

CARDINAL . A grant of legal aid expires upon a judgment of an appellate court . A new decision on legal aid has to be made if the convicted person wishes to institute further proceedings in order to lodge a cassation appeal with ORG . The relevant part of Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW provides :

“ A defence counsel appointed under the legalaid scheme in the cassation proceedings ... shall prepare and sign a cassation appeal ... or shall inform the court , in writing , that he or she has not found any grounds for lodging a cassation appeal ... If a cassation appeal ... is lodged , the defence counsel is entitled to represent the defendant in the subsequent proceedings . ”

CARDINAL . In its decision of CARDINAL DATE ( V ORG CARDINAL , OSNKW CARDINAL/CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ORG stated that cassation proceedings had a special character in that the judgment essentially became final after it had been upheld by the appellate court . Bearing in mind the special character of these proceedings , the court was of the view that at this stage the mere fact that the convicted person was granted legal aid was sufficient to ensure an effective exercise of his or her defence rights . It was the lawyer ’s task to analyse the case and establish whether there were grounds on which to lodge a cassation appeal against the judgment of the appellate court . If the lawyer was of the opinion that there were no grounds on which to do so , there was no legal basis in LAW that would either oblige the lawyer to prepare such an appeal against his or her better judgment , or to oblige the court to assign another lawyer to prepare such an appeal in the case .

CARDINAL . NORP In its decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG stated that the refusal of a legalaid lawyer to lodge a cassation appeal did not constitute a valid ground for granting retrospective leave to lodge such an appeal by another lawyer out of time ( V ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . It confirmed this ruling in a further decision of DATE . ORG observed that the court could only assign a new legalaid lawyer to the case if it were shown that the first lawyer had been negligent in his or her task of assessing whether a cassation appeal had any prospects of success . If this were not the case , a court was not obliged to assign a new legalaid lawyer to represent the convicted person and its refusal was not subject to appeal ( III KZ CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . ORG reiterated its position in a number of other decisions ( e.g. II KZ CARDINAL/CARDINAL , PERSON CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .
